poem:
**Mistaken Identity**

In Old Pueblo dust, the sun hangs low,  
ICE agents clutch vague descriptions like prayer beads,  
A marshal mistaken, snagged in their net,  
Name swapped with shadow, badge turned to doubt,  
Even in the libraries of the righteous,  
Errors walk tall, cloaked as ghosts,  
Some truths miscast in the glare of noon.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "US immigration agents mistakenly detain deputy marshal in Arizona A US marshal was detained by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) agents in Arizona, after being mistakenly identified as a man that agents were looking for, according to a statement from the US Marshals Service. The deputy marshal matched the “fit the general description of a subject being sought by ICE” and was detained at a federal building in the Old Pueblo in Tucson. Officials said". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
